I know that I was the one advocating capabilities,
but I think the examples show how difficult they
are to use in real life.

If I am looking at a page with my January
bank account history, I would like some way to
navigate back to the main menu....

If I am the WSJ, how do I restrict access while
at the same time allow users to refer to the same
document?

-Alex-

On Sun, 2 Mar 2003, Tyler Close wrote:

> On Saturday 01 March 2003 15:45, Chuck Hinson wrote:
> > Tyler Close wrote:
> > >For an explanation of how capability-based security could be
> > >applied using REST design principles, I suggest my own paper at:
> > >
> > >http://www.waterken.com/dev/Web/Calculus/
> > >
> > >The paper also uses tradeable electronic credit as an example, but
> > >with a different design. The paper describes a RESTful interface
> > >for tradeable electronic credit.
> >
> > I'm at a disadvantage here since I really don't understand the
> > capability model that's being described.
>
> The basics of the model are fairly simple. Based on your next
> sentence, it looks like you've already groked the main point.
>
> > However, reading the paper, I got the sense that security is
> > provided as a result of traversing a graph.
>
> That's correct. The graph basically says: "If a user has access to
> this resource, they are also authorized to use these other
> resources." You can tell which resources the user is not
> authorized to use by noticing that there is no way to get to those
> resources by traversing the graph. Having a simple and
> well-defined model like this makes it a lot easier to study your
> application security and make sure you got it right.
>
> > This doesnt seem terribly useful - why should I have to traverse
> > a graph to get to a resource every time I want to access the resource?
> >  Why can't I just directly access it.
>
> You can directly access it. Any resource in the graph can have a
> URI associated with it. You can use this URI to directly access
> the resource. The graph defines how you get additional URIs, given
> the ones you've already got.
>
> > I really dont get this.  Perhaps I'm dense, but it just doesn't seem
> > useful to have a world where everybody gets their own URI to a single
> > resource.  What happens to sharing and linking?
>
> You're not dense, just a little hard of hearing. ;) As I said in
> the last message, you're right, you wouldn't use this model to
> give everyone their own URI to a single, shared, read-only
> resource. You use this model to protect and share access to
> private resources.  Think more about your online banking interface
> than your Wall Street Journal subscription.
>
> For example, you might have a capability URL for your bank
> account. From this resource, you can navigate to resources that
> let you pay bills and view your withdrawal/deposit history. The
> account history might be composed of a different resource for each
> of the calendar months. At tax time, you might give your
> accountant the URIs for your January to December account history
> resources. Your accountant can then do up your tax forms, but
> cannot pay bills from your account.
>
> Tyler
